title: Travel firms urged to plan for terror crises
text:
Save 
Travel companies have been urged to create crisis management plans offering staff guidance on what to do if there is a terrorist attack. 
The warning from a specialist security firm comes in the wake of the Tunisia massacre near the resort town of Sousse, which left 38 tourists dead, including 30 First Choice and Thomson customers. 
Speaking to TTG , Henry Wilkinson, head of intelligence and analysis for the Risk Advisory Group, said travel firms should be wary of relying solely on advice from the Foreign Office when assessing the risk of terror attacks in destinations. 
He said tour operators should carry out independent assessments of potential threats and implement plans to deal with an attack.The global security consultancy currently works with international hotel chains and airlines. 
Wilkinson said the group’s assessment of the terrorism threat level in Tunisia had been higher than the FCO’s advice prior to the terrorist attack two weeks ago. 
He said the group had raised its threat level after March’s attack on tourists at the Bardo museum in Tunis. It has since raised it further following the Sousse atrocity. 
“Travel companies should have the capability to understand the threats and monitor the countries where they operate, and not just rely on FCO advice,” he said. “They have to be happy with the security arrangements in place. 
“This should also be done to monitor places where threats are dropping off because this could allow travel companies to develop opportunities in areas which may have suffered an attack some time ago.” 
Wilkinson said Morocco was a destination where it had lowered the threat level from terrorism in the past two years. 
He said tourism was the second most targeted commercial sector globally after the retail sector. 
Data shows there were 31 incidents of tourists being attacked across the world in the past 12 months. 
“Broadly speaking, the number of attacks have been consistent in the past few years - what has changed is that the number of fatalities has gone up recently,” said Wilkinson. 
Current FCO advice on Tunisia says “further terrorist attacks are likely” but it has stopped short of advising against all non-essential travel. 
Prime minister David Cameron has said this will be kept “under close review”.
